full_conversation: Therapist: Mr. Singh, today we'll begin imaginal exposure. How are you feeling about this?
Client: I'm quite nervous, to be honest. The idea of reliving that earthquake... it's not something I look forward to. I've spent years trying to forget it all. Why do we need to bring it up again?
Therapist: I understand your concern. This process helps reduce PTSD symptoms by—
Client: (interrupting) But won't it make things worse? I've managed to keep busy with work and family. Isn't that enough?
Therapist: It's natural to feel apprehensive. However, avoidance often—
Client: (sighs) I see. So, what exactly will happen during this... exposure?
Therapist: You'll recount the experience in detail. I'll guide you through it.
Client: (fidgeting) That sounds... intense. Will I be able to handle it? I mean, I'm not as young as I used to be, and with my anxiety...
Therapist: Your concerns are valid. We'll go at your pace and—
Client: (nods slowly) Alright. I appreciate that. But what if I panic? Or can't continue?
Therapist: We have techniques to help you stay grounded. Remember, you're safe here.
Client: (takes a deep breath) Okay. I trust you. It's just... this disaster changed everything for me. My family, our home... it's not easy to revisit.
Therapist: Your courage is commendable. This process, while challenging, can lead to healing.
Client: I hope so. I want to be free from these memories, for my wife and children's sake too. They've been so patient with me.
Therapist: That's a powerful motivation. Shall we begin?
Client: (straightens up) Yes, I think I'm ready. Or as ready as I'll ever be. Let's do this.
